abstract.text: Creates an anchored object query that matches any of the query descriptors you provided.

inlineContent.text: An array of descriptors that specify the types of samples that the query returns.

The anchor that the previous anchored object query returned. The anchor object corresponds to the last object that the previous anchored object query returned. The new query returns only samples and deleted objects that are newer than that object.
Pass
to receive all the matching samples and recently deleted objects currently in the HealthKit store.
The maximum number of samples that the query returned. If you want to return all matching samples, use
A block that the HealthKit store calls after gathering the initial results. This block takes the following parameters:
A reference to the query calling this block.
An array containing the samples this query returned, or
if an error occurred.
An array containing the deleted objects this query returned, or
if an error occurred.

An anchor object corresponding to the last object this query returned. Subsequent anchor queries use this value to receive new samples and deleted objects created after the query returned its initial results.

Use this initializer to create an anchored object query for data that matches any of the
objects. Each descriptor can specify a different data type.
After instantiating the query, call the
class’s

method to run it. Queries run on an anonymous background queue. As soon as the query is complete, the system executes the results handler on the background queue, returning samples that match any of the descriptors. You typically dispatch these results to the main queue to update the user interface.
The first time you call this method, pass
as the
parameter. This method returns all matching objects currently in the HealthKit store. Additionally, save the returned anchor object and pass it to the next query.

Anchor queries can also act as long-running queries. If you assign an update handler before executing the query, the query continues to monitor the HealthKit store after gathering the initial results. The system calls the update handler on a background queue whenever a matching sample is saved to or deleted from the HealthKit store. To cancel this query, call the store’s
method.

For example, the following code gathers and returns all step count and push count samples currently in the HeathKit store. It then continues to monitor the store and calls the handler again after any relevant changes.

code: let stepDescriptor = HKQueryDescriptor(sampleType: stepCountType, predicate: nil)
let pushDescriptor = HKQueryDescriptor(sampleType: pushCountType, predicate: nil)
// Create a handler to process results from the query.
Error?) -> Void = { (query, samples, deleted, newAnchor, error) in
// Process the samples and deleted objects here.
// To continue monitoring the HealthKit store in the background, set the

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
A query that returns changes to the HealthKit store, including a snapshot of new changes and continuous monitoring as a long-running query.
Creates an anchored object query that matches any of the query descriptors you provided.
Initializes a new anchored object query.
Initializes a new anchored object query.
An object that represents a sample that has been deleted from the HealthKit store.
The access point for all data managed by HealthKit.
Starts executing the provided query.
Stops a long-running query.
A value indicating that the query returns all the matching samples in the HealthKit store.
An object used to identify all the samples previously returned by an anchored object query.
A descriptor that specifies a set of samples based on the data type and a predicate.
A HealthKit sample represents a piece of data associated with a start and end time.
Create and run an anchored object query.
Describes an integer.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
A signed integer value type.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
